text:
The Windows installer distribution of Tomcat 5.5.x does not contain the 
startup scripts catalina.bat, setclasspath.bat, etc. It is quite weird since 
when you install the full instalation using the Tomcat Windows installer, 
you'll get less than what you would get from the zip distribution. 
 
Our NetBeans Tomcat integration currently relies on existence of those scripts 
and I believe that there are others with the same problem. I guess that normal 
Tomcat users would also appreciate having those scripts back.
creator: sherold@netbeans.org

text:
Well, this is on purpose. If you are embedding, then you should not be using the
.exe.
creator: remm@apache.org
sherold@netbeans.org
text:
Ok, now I understand that it is a feature. Is there any issue that describes why
it was removed? I could not find any reason for it.

> Well, this is on purpose. If you are embedding, then you should not be using
the .exe.


Am I suppose to start it always as a service then? I think it is very
uncomfortable for development, using the startup scripts is much more
convenient. Btw, if you start Tomcat as a service, you won't see the server output.

The weirdest thing about it is that the .exe distro does not contain some file
that come with the .zip distro. Usually when I have a program that comes in .exe
and .zip distribution, I expect the .exe distro to contain everything that the
.zip distro does + some additional tasks performed by installer (windows start
menu modification, windows services registration, etc).

In the current situation users might be forced to download both the .exe and the
.zip distribution.

Thanks for your answer.

creator: remm@apache.org
text:
The reason is that I don't like ugly things if they are not needed in most
cases. So the .bat are gone in this distribution. If you really need them for
some reason, you can get them from the .zip. Both downloads are small (put
together, smaller than Tomcat 5.0.x download).

creator: zikmund@netbeans.org
text:
Tomcat on Windows is usually (mostly!) used for development. And developers need
.bat files for comfortable running/stopping server. I don't see advantages of
running it as service in development time. Therefore I would expect .bat files
in full installation (not in standard installation).

I'm reopening. If you don't agree, please add some arguments or let's ask more
people for opinion. Thanks.

This issue HAS been discussed (i.e. more people voicing opinions, not just 
Remy) on the tomcat-dev list in the past, before the distros were changed.
creator: yoavs@computer.org
zikmund@netbeans.org
text:
OK then, thanks for explanation. Do you have a link to that thread? or at least
thread subject, please? ( your mailing archive seems to have some problems now :( )

We don't want to bother you. We are open source too, but explanation like "it's
ugly" is not acceptable for us, sorry. We just would like to understand.

Yeah, the Eyebrowse stuff is not my favorite.  I use MARC at AIMS.  The thread 
I referred to before was labelled [5.5] Packaging, you can see it at 
http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=tomcat-dev&w=2&r=1&s=packaging+5.5&q=b.

Basically, the logic is: the executable is for users who don't embed tomcat, 
just want to install it and run, i.e. low level of Tomcat familiarity.  The 
zip is for people who embed tomcat, customize the scripts, or otherwise have 
higher tomcat familiarity and corresponding needs.

If you want to discuss this further, please use the mailing list, and not 
bugzilla.  We can reopen this issue later if need be.  The mailing list gets 
more people watching, more voices, etc, and a better format anyways, e.g. for 
archival and subsequent searching ;)
creator: yoavs@computer.org
